comments: We learned about various linguistic varieties, their histories, and their sociolinguistic implications in the US.
I learned about the origins of American English and how immigrants learn and live with English.
I got to know some extremely helpful books on language variety in the US.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The content of this course was interesting. Lectures were not as engaging, and course materials (updated syllabus, class handouts, lecture recordings) were hard to access.

At first, as an auditor I was given a lot of opportunities to share my answers to the instructors questions, which I appreciated indeed. Later, however, I was interrupted at the beginning of my answer to one of the questions: the instructor thanked me for my contribution and said I should let the others answer. I know my answer wasnt perfect, but if I had been given a chance to finish what I was saying, it would have been right.

This left me wondering what I did wrong and feeling anxious about me possibly grabbing the spotlight and not letting credit students speak. 

The way I see it, the instructor should have established the participation mode that she feels is right from the outset. I would understand it if she let me as an auditor know that Im expected to only listen to and perhaps ask questions. However, by directing some of the questions right to me on previous classes, the instructor set the pace in which I felt I could share my answers just like other students. Thats why I didnt expect to be interrupted at all, which was indeed discouraging.

After that my participation mode got down to very low because I didnt want my answers to spoil what the instructor was creating in class.

The assignments felt a little heavy considering the reading load, especially for a class that wasn't marketed as a higher level seminar. I would have preferred different discussions on reading, but the class was very structured which is nice.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The handouts were well-structured and video examples provided illustrated very well what we were learning.

The fact that the lectures were live but also you could do the assignments if you happened to miss one was nice, I wish the handouts were available on Canvas for review later, but the professor was very understanding of circumstances changing.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to a student interested in sociolinguistics. For linguistics majors, this is a very different course than what we are used to in the major.

I would recommend this class to someone who is interested in historical and sociological aspects of language, less so the technicalities of linguistics. As an ERM major, this class fit well into the larger diaspora of what I would consider with the major. But also, I'm not sure how it will look without Professor Burns.
